awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Developing Smart and Autonomous Internet-of-Things Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Due to the pervasiveness of the Internet and wireless networking, mobile devices are increasingly being interconnected through the system described as the Internet-of-Things (IoT). Coupled with advancements in integrated sensor technologies, IoT has generated a new wave of opportunities for cooperation and collaboration between devices, machines and humans to create smart systems. Motivated by the wide array of opportunities in the IoT space, this Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site will target developing smart and autonomous IoT systems. The REU site exposes students to emerging areas of computer science and engineering and provides them with the opportunities for hands-on research training and experience in emerging smart technologies. This research experience, along with the proposed student development activities, encourages students to continue on to further their education. The program particularly recruits students from campuses and community colleges in rural and low-income communities across Georgia, as these students often are first-generation college attendees and/or have limited opportunities to work with the latest technologies.

The vision of the REU site is to encourage competitive research in early stages of undergraduate students' career and motivate them to pursue higher education to conduct highly skilled research and development in future. The site supports 10 participants for an 8-week period in the summer of each REU year. The participants work in teams on specific projects mentored by the REU site’s organizing group that consists of five faculty mentors, two mentors from industry and four graduate student mentors. Each of these projects will use a variety of hardware, ranging from sensors to mobile devices to drones, and will provide an experience and opportunity to the students in developing their skills to design end-to-end IoT systems. The specific intellectual merits of the program are derived from diverse projects in IoT and autonomous systems. In addition to the technical development, students get training on personal and professional development such as advise on pursuing graduate studies, primer on ethics and professionalism in research, and exercise in writing and presenting technical work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This REU Site has completed a 3 year cycle and supported a total of 27 participants (10, 9 and 8) for an eight--week period in the summer of each REU year (canceled in Summer 2020, Summer of 2021-2023). The key objectives of the REU were:

1. To provide research experience for undergraduates, primarily from the under-represented minority communities, on smart and autonomous technologies and Internet-of-Things (IoT).

2. To create a cohort experience for the UG research participants and provide a learn-through-experience teaching of team work culture, progression of research and troubleshooting, articulation of results and presentation.

3. To create a positive experience among the UG student participants to either pursue graduate studies or be motivated to take up career positions in next generation smart and autonomous technology fields and areas.

4. To provide the UG student participants a hands-on overview of research conducted in R1 institutions and how such research impacts the industry, demonstrated through industry talks and seminars.

Intellectual Merits: Students worked on individual or team research projects and received professional development training. The research projects exposed them to a variety of hardware, ranging from sensors to mobile devices to drones, and an experience in designing end-to-end IoT systems. The students also learned about sustainability, recycling and environment preservation through a hands-on project based approach. The REU students received training in professional development, such as advice on pursuing graduate studies, resume preparation, ethics and technical writing.

Broader Impacts: The REU has trained graduate students to mentor undergraduate students on research and create materials for professional development activities such as slides, multimedia and technical paper writing. The REU has also resulted in multiple UG research publications and presentations in conferences. For one of the REU projects, its lead student has moved the work towards technology transition towards their upstart in Oklahoma that develops a mobile camera based technology for detecting skin cancer. Over 10 students have reached out to the PIs and faculty mentors for graduate school recommendations, of which 5 have accepted/started attending graduate school. The REU has resulted in generation of materials for use in teaching classes in the CS department, particularly for computer vision, robotics, computer networks, database, mobile systems and IoT courses.
